summary.para: This class is primarily used for internal debugging, tracing and profiling off the MindSqualls API. To use it you will have to change the class access modifier from "internal" to "public".
Call this method when entering a method.
Call this method when exiting a method.
Call this method to indicate that a method has been visited.
This class sorts of combines MethodEnter() and MethodExit().
Use this method to enter a note with the trace.
Abstract class representing the NXT communication protocol.

remarks.para: The communication protocol for the NXT brick is specified in the documents:

Lego Mindstorms NXT,
Bluetooth Developer Kit,
Appendix 1: LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Communication protocol
- and:
Appendix 2: LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Direct commands

A special thanks goes to Bram Fokke for his NXT# project:
http://nxtsharp.fokke.net/
Without his work, I doubt very much if my own work would have gotten off the ground. I have even st... ehem... borrowed a bit of his code here and there. However the major part of the code is my own.

summary.para: Flag indicating if a reply should always be recieved.

member.returns: The reply from the NXT brick, or null

summary.para: Indicates if connected to the NXT brick.
Class representing a port with no sensor attached.

remarks.para: Used as base class for the specific sensor classes.

summary.para: Abstract class used as superclass for the NxtMotor and NxtSensor classes.

remarks.para: This class has been modified from using System.Timers.Timer (in versions 1.0 and 1.1) to using System.Threading.Timer in order to be able to function with the compact framework (i.e. to run on a PDA). A special thanks to Giorgio T. for his suggestion.

summary.para: The NXT brick that the sensor/motor is attached to.
This event is triggered by the auto-poll timer.
The NXT brick that the sensor/motor is attached to.
Indicates if the sensor, or motor, is auto-polled or not.

value.para: A positive value means that the sensor is auto-pooled, and with the indicated interval i milliseconds.
Zero, or a negative value, means that the sensor is not auto-polled.

summary.para: This event is fired when the sensor, or motor, is polled.
The port the sensor is attached to.
The port on the NXT brick that the sensor is attached to.
This empty Pool-method effectively cancels polling on this port.
Abstract class representing a Passive Sensor.

remarks.para: According to the LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Hardware Developer Kit p. 7, sensors is divided into three types: active sensors (e.g. Robotics Invention Systems sensors), passive sensors (e.g. the NXT touch, light, and sound sensors), and digital sensors (e.g. the NXT ultrasonic sensor and the HiTechnic compass sensor). The three abstract classes NxtActiveSensor, NxtPassiveSensor, and NxtDigitalSensor reflect this.

summary.para: The data from the previous poll of the sensor.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Indicates if the sensor should supply its own light.
The intensity of the measured light.
This event is fired whenever the measured light intensity passes above the compare-intensity.
This event is fired whenever the measured light intensity passes below the compare-intensity.
Class representing the Acceleration / Tilt Sensor sensor from HiTechnic: http://www.hitechnic.com

remarks.para: A special thanks to the people at HiTechnic for providing me with the necessary technical information.
Also a special thanks to Ronny H. for providing me with a qualified implementation details on the acceleration sensor before I had purchased my own copy.

summary.para: Abstract class representing a Digital sensor, i.e. a sensor using the I2C protocol.

remarks.para: The "Device Memory Arrangement" for a Digital sensor is specified at p. 10 of the document:

LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT,
Hardware Developer Kit
The Ultrasonic sensor protocol is specifed in appendix 7 of the HDK.
"Digital I/O Communication Methods" is also explained in the Executable File Specification document, p. 70-72.

According to the LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Hardware Developer Kit p. 7, sensors is divided into three types: active sensors (e.g. Robotics Invention Systems sensors), passive sensors (e.g. the NXT touch, light, and sound sensors), and digital sensors (e.g. the NXT ultrasonic sensor and the HiTechnic compass sensor). The three abstract classes NxtActiveSensor, NxtPassiveSensor, and NxtDigitalSensor reflect this.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.NxtDigitalSensor.Send(System.Byte,System.Byte[])

summary.para: Sends an I2C request to the Ultrasonic sensor, and receive the reply if applicable.

member.returns: The reply from the sensor, or a null-value

summary.para: Both the Ultrasonic sensor and the Compass plus Color sensors from HiTecnic uses 0x02 as the device address. However the documentation do not put any limits to this value.
Returns the version of the sensor.
Returns the name of the manufacturer, e.g. "LEGO".
Reads the value of the variable stored at the address.
Reads the value of the variable stored at the two consecutive bytes at the address.
Change this value, to finetune the value of the acceleration sensor.
The current value, = 9.82/206.3, is the best fit for my own sensor.

remarks.para: The component used in the sensor is only guaranteed to be accurate to +/- 10%.

summary.para: Returns the current heading to a 2-degree accuracy.

This event is fired when the Heading passes inside the Range-interval.
This event is fired when the Heading passes outside the Range-interval.

remarks.para: The I2C protocol for the Ultrasonic sensor is specified in the document:

Lego Mindstorms NXT,
Hardware Developer Kit,
Appendix 7: LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Ultrasonic Sensor I2C communication protocol

A special thanks goes to Dick Swan and Templar for their invaluable explanations in:
http://forums.nxtasy.org/index.php?showtopic=141
The resulting code stated out being part of the NxtUltrasonicSensor class but has since been moved to the NxtDigitalSensor class.

summary.para: Returns the "factory zero" of the sensor.
Returns the "factory scale factor" of the sensor.
Returns the factory scale divisor of the sensor.
Returns the measurement units if the sensor, e.g. "10E-2m".
The data from the previous poll of the sensor.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Returns the measured distance in cm.
This event is fired if the sensor detects an object within the trigger distance.
This event is fired if the sensor does not detect an object within the trigger distance.
Delegate used for the NXT-G like events implemented in the various sensors.
Delegate used when a motor or sensor is polled.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Indicating if the sensor-button is pressed or not.
This event is fired when the touch sensor is pressed.
This event is fired when the touch sensor is released.
Delegate used for the NXT-G like events implemented in the motor.

remarks.para: Notice that commLink is an instance of NxtCommunicationProtocol, not NxtBluetoothConnection as you might expect. This is to ensure that commLink could just as well be a NxtUsbConnection if and when that class is created in the future. The future NxtUsbConnection-class will also inherit NxtCommunicationProtocol as NxtBluetoothConnection does.

summary.para: The motor attached to port A.
The motor attached to port B.
The motor attached to port C.
This property returns the name of the currently running program, or null if no program is running.
Set the property to a program name to run the program, or to null to stop any running program.
The programs currently stored in the NXT brick.
The sounds currently stored in the NXT brick.
The name of the NXT brick.

Class representing the Color sensor from HiTechnic: http://www.hitechnic.com

remarks.para: A special thanks to the people at HiTechnic for providing me with the necessary technical information.

summary.para: Returns the current detection level for the color red.
Returns the current detection level for the color green.
Returns the current detection level for the color blue.
Returns the current sensor analog signal level for the color red.
Returns the current sensor analog signal level for the color green.
Returns the current sensor analog signal level for the color blue.
Returns a single 6 bit number color index. Bits 5 and 4 encode the red signal level, bits 3 and 2 encode the green signal level and bits 1 and 0 encode the blue signal levels.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.HiTechnicColorSensor.NormalizedRedReading

summary.para: Return the current relative level for the red color component.

member.remarks: The normalization sets the highest value of the three red, green and blue reading to 255 and adjusts the other two proportionately.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.HiTechnicColorSensor.NormalizedGreenReading

summary.para: Return the current relative level for the green color component.

member.remarks: The normalization sets the highest value of the three red, green and blue reading to 255 and adjusts the other two proportionately.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.HiTechnicColorSensor.NormalizedBlueReading

summary.para: Return the current relative level for the blue color component.

member.remarks: The normalization sets the highest value of the three red, green and blue reading to 255 and adjusts the other two proportionately.

summary.para: Returns a single number color estimate.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Indicating if the sensor should return results as dB or as dBA (adjusted for the human ear).

This event is fired whenever the measured sound level passes below the compare-level.

summary.para: Puts the motors into the idle state.

According to the LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Hardware Developer Kit p. 7, sensors is divided into three types: active sensors (e.g. Robotics Invention Systems sensors), passive sensors (e.g. the NXT touch, light, and sound sensors), and digital sensors (e.g. the NXT ultrasonic sensor and the HiTechnic compass sensor). The three abstract classes NxtActiveSensor, NxtPassiveSensor, and NxtDigitalSensor reflect this.
